title: Colliding blocks launched by different springs

content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) The figure above shows Case 1 of an experiment. Initially, block A is held in place while in contact with a horizontal spring with spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that is compressed a distance <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and fixed to a wall. The following events occur. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A is released from rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the ideal spring reaches its uncompressed length, and block A leaves the spring. At time <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A collides with and sticks to identical block B, which is initially at rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A and block B are sliding together along the surface. Assume there is negligible friction between each block and the surface. (a) Indicate whether the speed of the center of mass of the two-block system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) The figure above shows Case 1 of an experiment. Initially, block A is held in place while in contact with a horizontal spring with spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that is compressed a distance <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and fixed to a wall. The following events occur. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A is released from rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the ideal spring reaches its uncompressed length, and block A leaves the spring. At time <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A collides with and sticks to identical block B, which is initially at rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A and block B are sliding together along the surface. Assume there is negligible friction between each block and the surface. (a) Indicate whether the speed of the center of mass of the two-block system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

(b) Indicate whether the mechanical energy of the two-block system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

(c) Indicate whether the speed of the center of mass of the two-block system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

(d) Indicate whether the mechanical energy of the two-block system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

In Case 2 shown above, the setup is identical to Case 1 except that a stiffer spring is used. The spring in Case 2 has a spring constant <math alttext="k sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that is greater than <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The spring is compressed the same distance, <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, before block A is released. As in Case 1, the blocks stick together when they collide. (e) Is the speed of the blocks after the collision in Case 2 greater than, less than, or the same as the speed of the blocks after the collision in Case 1?
(f) Briefly explain your reasoning for part (e).

Students attempt to determine a general equation for the speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the blocks after the collision. A spring with spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is initially compressed a distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A has mass <math alttext="m sub a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and block B has mass <math alttext="m sub b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The students come up with the following two equations. Equation 1: <math alttext="v equals, C sub 1, times, open parenthesis, the fraction with numerator m sub B, end sub, plus m sub a, and denominator the square root of, k times m sub A, end root, end fraction, close parenthesis, times d" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> <mo>=</mo> <msub> <mrow> <mi>C</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mi>m</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>B</mi> </mrow> </msub> <mo>+</mo> <msub> <mrow> <mi>m</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>A</mi> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msqrt> <mrow> <mi>k</mi> <msub> <mrow> <mi>m</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>A</mi> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mi>d</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> Equation 2: <math alttext="v equals, C sub 2, times, open parenthesis, the fraction with numerator the square root of, k times m sub A, end root, and denominator m sub A, end sub, plus m sub B, end sub, end fraction, close parenthesis, times d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>k</mi><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> In the two equations, <math alttext="C sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are positive constants with appropriate units. (g) Without algebraic manipulation of equations or deriving the correct equation, explain which equation better supports your explanation for the speed of the two blocks in part (f).

The graph above shows the displacement of block A while it is in contact with the spring for Case 1 and Case 2. The solid line corresponds to either Case 1 or Case 2, while the dashed line corresponds to the other case. (h) Does the solid-line curve best correspond to Case 1 (with a smaller spring constant) or to Case 2 (with a larger spring constant)? Explain your reasoning.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
